ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: We learned everything ranging from the success of Netflix to the decline of cable and network television. I learned so much about historical, aesthetic and organizational evolution of television.
I learned a full history of the broadcast TV stations and the interworkings of the TV industry. Additionally, we had some interesting discussions about streaming companies, such as Netflix.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths:
Very interesting, very in-depth, really enjoyed the papers and the final project. Professor Johnson was a wonderful professor.
Weaknesses: 
For a seminar it felt like a lecture.
I think Professor Johnson is a great personality who knows so much about the industry. I do wish we got to have more discussions than lectures.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely; I learned a lot. The Professor is very kind and empathetic.

I would recommend the class. However, you must be very interested in the topic, or else the lectures would be boring. Additionally, the essays are a lot of research and self-teaching. So it is fun when you have a passion you want to research, but I think would be tedious otherwise.
